data.title: Return to Yesterday (1940)
data.meta_description: Robert Maine is torn between returning to the glamour of Hollywood and working with a small theatre company in England.
data.text:
Robert Stevenson’s comedy-drama. A man (Clive Brook) and a woman (Anna Lee) are undecided between going back to the attraction of Hollywood and employed with a tiny theatre firm in England.

The story concerns a movie actor on his way back to the United States, who chooses to stop off at a small English seaside town in an effort to evoke the contentment of his childhood.

Clive Brook and Anna Lee both give good performances in their respective parts as Robert Maine and Carol Sands. Robert is the man remembering his childhood, while Carol is the woman who he falls in love with.

However, the two are then undecided over exactly what they should do and where they should go.…

An early film from Michael Balcon’s Ealing Studios, but before they had fully gained their identity. A light film, I suppose it is a comedy, but it isn’t particularly amusing. Clive Brook is the Hollywood star on a visit back home to England: dissatisfied with his lot and nostalgically looking back to his youth, he does a bunk and joins up with a troupe of actors putting on a play at an end of the pier theatre in a seaside resort. Anna Lee is the young and enthusiastic actress, David Tree is the young playwright: they are in youthful love, but when Brook turns up he turns her head and she falls for the charismatic older actor. But it is…
